life and marriage - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>         <topcClas>Income, property and investment - Economics</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p><b>Safe Room Access FRS data</b><br> Safe Room access datasets for FRS data from 2005/06 are available in addition to the versions available under the standard End User Licence (EUL), held at the UK Data Archive under SN 7196, Family Resources Survey, 2005/06-2012/13 and Households Below Average Income, 1994/95-2012/13: Safe Room Access. These data replace SNs 5839, 6083, 6253 and 6532, which were previously available under Special Licence.<br> <br> The Safe Room access data are currently only available to UK HE/FE applicants  and for access from the UK Data Archive's Safe Room at the University of Essex, Colchester. Prospective users of the Safe Room access version of the FRS/HBAI will need to fulfil requirements additional to those associated with standard End User Licence datasets. Full details of the application requirements are available from <a href="http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/media/178323/secure_frs_application_guidance.pdf" title="Guidance on applying for the Family Resources Survey: Secure Access">Guidance on applying for the Family Resources Survey: Secure Access</a>.<br> <br> Further information about the FRS can be found on the <a href="http://research.dwp.gov.uk/asd/frs" title="Family Resources Survey">Family Resources Survey</a> pages on the Department for Work and Pensions web site.<br> </abstract>       <abstract>The Family Resources Survey aims to: support the monitoring of the social security programme; support the costing and modelling of changes to national insurance contributions and social security benefits; provide better information for the forecasting of benefit expenditure. From April 2002, the Family Resources Survey was extended to include Northern Ireland.<br> <br> <B>Edition History:</B><br> For the third edition of the 2002-2003 survey, the new grossing regime, GROSS 3, was included.<br> <br> For the fourth edition, revised data for variable NINRV has been included, along with corrections to variable HHRENT. Variables AGE and SSTRTREG have been suppressed. For full version history see study documentation and READ file below.<br> <br> For the fifth edition (October 2014) the data have been re-grossed following revision of the FRS grossing methodology to take account of the 2011 Census mid-year population estimates. New variable GROSS4 has been added to the dataset.</br><br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br> Household characteristics (composition, tenure type); tenure and housing costs including Council Tax, mortgages, insurance, water and sewage rates; consumer durables; vehicles; use of health services; welfare/school milk and meals; educational grants and loans; children in education; informal care (given and received); occupation and employment; health restrictions on work; children's health; wage details; self-employed earnings; travel to work; personal and occupational pension schemes; income and benefit receipt; income from pensions and trusts, royalties and allowances, maintenance and other sources; income tax payments and refunds; National Insurance contributions; earnings from odd jobs; children's earnings; interest and dividends; investments; National Savings products; assets.<br> Standard Measures<br> Standard Occupational Classification</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2002-04-01T00:00:00Z">April 2002</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2003-03-01T00:00:00Z">March 2003</collDate>         <nation>Northern Ireland</nation>         <nation>Great Britain</nation>         <geogUnit>Government Office Regions</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Families/households</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Families</universe>         <universe>Households</universe>         <universe>Private households in the United Kingdom.</universe>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>annual - analysed on a financial year basis.</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>Department for Work and Pensions</dataCollector>         <sampProc>Multi-stage stratified random sample</sampProc>         <deviat>28,710 (obtained)</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview</collMode>         <collMode>CAPI</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used. See documentation for details</weight>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage. See <a href=http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/conditions.aspx>terms and conditions of access</a> for further information.</restrctn>         <contact><a
